Fig. 1 (a) Crystal structure of CoCr2O4; (b) (1 0 0) surface of CoCr2O4; (c) Mn-doped (1 0 0) surface of CoCr2O4; (d) V and Mn co-doped (1 0 0) surface of CoCr2O4; (d) Ti and Mn co-doped (1 0 0) surface of CoCr2O4, where Co atoms are blue, Cr atoms are gray, Mn atoms are purple, V atoms are green, Ti atoms are pink and O atoms are red. Fig 1 Fig. 2 The optimized configurations of NH3 adsorbed on the surfaces of Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4 (100), Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4(100) and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4(100). Blue and white balls represent N and H atoms, respectively. Being based on the first-principles calculation method of density functional theory, our work calculated the optimized configuration of CoCr2O4(100) before and after co-doping of Mn and V(Ti). The adsorption behaviors of NH3, NO, NO2 and other gas molecules on the catalyst before and after doping were simulated. The optimized structures and related energy distribution of NH3 dehydrogenation reaction and SCR reaction on Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts were also fully studied. Our results reveal that the co-doping of heteroatom towards CoCr2O4(100) may result in electron migration and lattice dislocations as well as improving the surface acid activity. Therefore, the co-doping of Mn and V or Mn and Ti are believed to improve the adsorption of NH3, NO, NO2 and other gas molecules on the CoCr2O4 catalyst and significantly reduce the activation energy barrier of the NH3 dehydrogenation reaction and the SCR reaction. Furthermore, we studied the adsorption of SO2 and H2O on the co-doped catalyst, which exhibited that the co-doping of Mn and Ti may effectively improve the water and sulfur resistance of the catalyst. Our research are expected to be full of important theoretical guiding significance for the development, preparation and modification of cobalt-chromium spinel catalysts. Graphical abstract The adsorption of NH3, NO, NO2 and other small gas molecules on the surface of the CoCr2O4(100) catalyst co-doped with Mn, V and Mn, Ti and the reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR are revealed. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective catalytic reduction NOx removal Co-doping Reaction pathway Density functional theory 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are well-known to be produced by the combustion of fossil fuels [1]. They are not only the main cause of acid rain, but also react with hydrocarbons to form photochemical smog [2–4], which has become the severe air pollutants, ranking only second to inhalable particulate matter and sulfur dioxide [5,6]. As a matter of course, the investigation of effective NOx emission controlling measurements is of great significance to improving the quality of the atmospheric environment. In terms of this issue, various countries have formulated increasingly stringent emission standards of exhausting NOx in recent years [7–10]. Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) has been the most accepted and widely used denitration technology in the field of denitration [11–14], which depict that under the action of a catalyst, NOx react with a reducing agent (such as NH3) to generate N2 and H2O [15–17]. Due to the advantages of high denitrification efficiency, mature process technology, and reliable operation, SCR technology has become one of the most promising technical routes to meet NOx emission regulations [18–21]. The core of SCR technology lies in the choice of catalysts and metal oxide catalysts are commonly used [22]. However, in general, single metal oxides normally have low reactivity and are easy to be poisoned [23–25]. By means of physically mixing or doping a variety of metal oxides, the composite catalysts will display desired performance [26,27]. Wang et al. [28] found that the mesoporous Fe-doped CeO2 catalyst with modified organic sulfate functional group showed excellent activity in the temperature range of 250–450 °C, and the NOx conversion rate exceeded 80%. Ren et al. [29] studied surface Ce doping can increase the adsorption energy of modified γ-Fe2O3 catalyst for NO and NH3, and reduce the activation energy barrier of the step that determines the SCR reaction rate. Si et al. [30] reported that Sn doping improves the redox performance of TiO2, NH3/NO adsorption and the amount of surface chemisorbed oxygen, and promotes the SCR reaction. Tang et al. [31] proposed that Ce modification significantly promotes the low-temperature activity and resistance to SO2 and/or H2O of Mn-Fe catalysts. Li et al. [32] used Mo as a bulk dopant to improve the NH3-SCR performance of CeO2/TiO2 catalyst, and synthesized a new type of CeO2/TiO2-MoO3 (Ce/TM) catalyst. It shows 100% NO conversion rate at 60,000 mlg−1h−1 at 200–350 °C, and has high tolerance to H2O and SO2 at 250°C. Wei et al. [33] discussed in detail the deactivation mechanism of SO2, H2O, alkali/alkaline earth metals (K, Na, Ca) and heavy metals (As, Pb, etc.) on Mn based catalysts, and analyzed and compared the different regeneration methods of poisoning caused by various poisons. Zhao et al. [34] summarized the chemical reactions on the surface of vanadium-titanium-based selective catalytic reduction (SCR) denitration catalysts, and believed that the SCR mechanism of the reaction of NH3 and NO to generate N2 and H2O followed the Eley-Rideal type mechanism. NH2NO was found to be an important intermediate in the SCR reaction, and the effects of H2O, SO2, and metals on SCR catalysts were also summarized. In previous studies [35], we concluded that the doping of Mn can improve the catalytic activity of CoCr2O4 catalyst for denitration. But the anti-poisoning performance of Mn0.9Co0.1Cr2O4, especially the sulfur resistance is barely satisfactory. We consider that partial substitution of Co and Cr cations of CoCr2O4 will create a multi-component metal oxide. On account of the different valence states for various metal cations, this approach may greatly enhance the electron transfer in the catalytic system, and the resulting synergistic effect can remarkably improve the catalytic performance. In this study, being based on the density functional theory, we calculated the promotion effect of Mn, V co-doping and Mn, Ti co-doping on the CoCr2O4 catalyst for the selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3. Our work are expected to provide theoretical guidance for the design of spinel oxide catalysts. 2 Computational methods and model 2.1 Computational methods This article mainly uses the CASTEP module in the Materials Studio simulation software, and the exchange correlation can use the PBE-based generalized gradient approximation (GGA-PBE) [36,37]. The semi-empirical Tkatchenko-Scheffler (TS) was included for dispersion correction of van der Waals. hen performing the geometric optimization of the adsorption structure, the convergence standards of energy, force and displacement are set to 1.0 × 10−5 Ha, 0.001 Ha/Å, and 0.001 Å, respectively, and the K point of the Brillouin zone is set to 2 × 4 × 1. The adsorption energy of gas molecules on the surface is defined as: (1) E ads = E slab + molecule − E slab − E molecule In the formula, Eads is the adsorption energy, eV; Etotal is the total energy of the substrate plus the molecule, eV; Eslab is the energy of the substrate surface, eV; Emolecule is the energy of the small molecule, eV. According to the definition, Eads is a negative value, indicating that the adsorption exotherm, the greater the absolute value, the stronger the adsorption effect. The reaction pathway is composed of intermediate (IM), transition state (TS) and final state (FS). All transition states along the different NH3-SCR reaction pathways are searched using the linear synchronous transit/quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) method. The reaction energy barrier is defined as the following formula: (2) E α = E TS − E Reactant ETS represents the energy of the transition state and EReactant represents the energy of the reactant. 2.2 Models For the calculation of the doped surface model, since the atomic species and coordination environment of the surface cut-off layer have a direct effect on gas adsorption, in order to directly study the effect of Mn, V co-doping and Mn, Ti co-doping on gas adsorption performance, we cut all the cut-off layer of the low-index surface contains Mn, V or Ti atoms. The optimized CoCr2O4 has the lowest energy as shown in Fig. 1 (a). The low-index (100) crystal plane has low surface energy and is easy to be exposed to the air atmosphere, so this crystal plane is used for DFT calculation for further research. Fig. 1(b) is a cut of the (100) plane of CoCr2O4. Fig. 1(c) is the configuration of Mn doping on CoCr2O4 (100). Fig. 1 (d) and (e) are the configuration of CoCr2O4 (100) planes co-doped with Mn and V, and co-doped with Mn and Ti, where Mn replaces Co to occupy tetrahedral void positions, and V or Ti replaces Cr to occupy octahedral void positions. The possible adsorption sites on the catalyst surface are marked. In the following study, we have considered the adsorption on each site. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Study on the adsorption performance of catalyst gas molecules 3.1.1 The adsorption of NH3 The adsorption and dissociation of NH3 on the acidic sites on the catalyst surface is an important initial step of the NH3-SCR reaction. Therefore, we first calculated the adsorption model of NH3 molecules on the CoCr2O4(100) surface co-doped with Mn, V and Mn, Ti by means of first-principles calculations on the atomic scale. Co, Cr and doped Mn and V (Ti) ions on the surface of the catalyst act as Lewis acid sites. When NH3 is adsorbed on the Lewis acid site of CoCr2O4, the N atoms of NH3 will coordinate with Co, Cr and doped Mn, V, Ti atoms, where the NH3 displays vertical adsorption behavior or is slightly inclined. The corresponding optimized structure is shown in Fig. 2 . We summarized that the adsorption energies, structural parameters and Mulliken charges of NH3 at different Lewis acid sites in Table 1 . The calculated results show that for the Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts, doped Mn, V and Ti are the main NH3 adsorption sites. And it is worth noting that co-doping also improves the acidity of Co and Cr sites to a certain extent. In the two co-doped structures, the Mn is the most acidic site, corresponding to -2.18 and -2.12 eV, respectively. Obviously, the bond length between the metal site and the adsorbed gas molecule is significantly shortened after doping. From the electron density difference graph in Fig. 3 , it is notable that in the co-doped structure, NH3 transfers more charge into the metal site, which corresponds well to the enhancement of adsorption. In addition, the co-doping of Mn and V improves the acidity of the metal sites on the substrate more significantly than the co-doping of Mn and Ti. { C o 2 + Cr 2 3 + O 4 2 − + xM n 4 + + y V 5 + = Mn x 4 + ( Co x − 4 y 2 + 1 − Co 3 y 1 + ) V y 5 + ( Cr 2 x − y 3 + 2 − Cr x 2 + ) O 4 2 − + xC o 2 + + yC r 3 + Mn O 2 + 1 2 V 2 O 5 = Mn Co • • + V Cr • • + 4 e ′ + 9 4 O 2 ( g ) { C o 2 + Cr 2 3 + O 4 2 − + xM n 4 + + yT i 4 + = Mn x 4 + ( Co x − 3 y 2 + 1 − Co 2 y 1 + ) Ti y 4 + ( Cr 2 x − y 3 + 2 − Cr x 2 + ) O 4 2 − + xC o 2 + + yC r 3 + Mn O 2 + Ti O 2 = Mn Co • • + Ti Cr • + 3 e ′ + 2 O 2 ( g ) We know that the atomic numbers of V, Ti, and Cr are close, Mn and Co also have similar atomic numbers, thence they have similar ionic radius. Meanwhile, based on defect chemical reaction mechanism, V, Ti, and Mn also have higher ionization potentials, which makes V, Ti and Mn is easily introduced into CoCr2O4 spinel through doping to form a valence control semiconductor. The introduction of V5+, Ti4+, and Mn4+ changes the ion electricity price, resulting in a new local energy level. Just like the above two sets of defect reaction equations, doped Mn4+ occupies the position of Co2+, V5+ and Ti4+ occupy the position of Cr3+ in the crystal lattice. But after adding a Mn4+ ion, V5+ and Ti4+ ion, will generate excess positive charge in the crystal, which is observably more than the charge generated when only Mn4+ is doped. In order to maintain electrical neutrality, Co2+ will trap electrons to form Co1+, and Cr3+ will get electrons to form Cr2+. The trapped electrons are only in a semi-bound state and are easily transferred to the adsorbed gas molecules(Aad + e → A-ad). Therefore, the electron transfer between the Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts and NH3 is more, which corresponds to a larger adsorption energy. In addition, V5+ provides more charge than Ti4+, that is why the adsorption of small gas molecules on the Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst is stronger. 3.1.2 The adsorption of NO and NO2 According to the adsorption behavior of NO on the surface of CoCr2O4, the adsorption position of NO on the surface of Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 mainly selects the doped Mn, V, and Ti sites. By comparing the adsorption energy of different adsorption sites, the model with larger adsorption energy is selected. The rest of the models are not considered in this article. The NO adsorption configuration is shown in Fig. 4 . The adsorption energy, surface structure parameters and Mulliken charge distribution of NO adsorption are shown in Table 2 . On the Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst, the adsorption energy of NO on the Mn site at the N end is -2.35 eV, and the adsorption energy on the V site was -1.74 eV. For the Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst, the adsorption energy of NO at the N-terminal on the Mn site is -2.32 eV, and the adsorption energy on the Ti site is -1.73 eV. It can be observed that the adsorption energy of NO is importantly increased after doping, and the co-doping of Mn and V and the co-doping of Mn and Ti have a stronger adsorption effect on NO than that with only Mn doping, but there is little difference between the two co-doped models. NO2 can promote the "fast SCR" reaction, which mainly manifest in improving the low-temperature catalytic activity. Therefore, we calculated the adsorption characteristics of NO2 molecules. Compared to the previous calculation of the adsorption of NO2 on the CoCr2O4 catalyst, we found that NO2 is preferentially adsorbed on the surface metal sites. Therefore, for the two catalysts Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4, through the comparison of adsorption sites and adsorption energy, we have selected the model with larger adsorption energy as shown in Fig. 5 , NO2 is adsorbed on the doped Mn, V and Ti sites, respectively, and the rest of the models are not considered in this paper. The corresponding structural parameters, Mulliken charge and adsorption energy are listed in Table 3 . The Mn, V co-doped and Mn, Ti co-doped CoCr2O4 catalyst has a significant promotion effect on the adsorption of NO2. We can easily see that the two co-doping, respectively, increase the adsorption energy of NO2 on Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4 from -2.30 to -2.74 and -2.55 eV. In general, the co-doping of Mn and V is more efficient than the co-doping of Mn and Ti for the adsorption of gas molecules on the CoCr2O4 catalyst. 3.2 The SCR NOx removal reaction process on anaerobic condition 3.2.1 NH3 dehydrogenation reaction The dehydrogenation process of NH3 on Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4, Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts is shown in Fig. 6 . On the three catalysts, the best adsorption site for NH3 is the Mn. The adsorbed NH3 molecules can be oxidized by the lattice oxygen and remove H atoms to form NH2, and then one H atom in NH2 continues to be attracted by the nearest lattice oxygen and continues to dehydrogenate to form NH. NH may continue to be oxidized by the surface lattice oxygen, leaving only one N atom at the Mn site, and the dissociated H will react with the surface lattice oxygen to form OH fragments. By comparing with the previous work we did on the Mn-doped CoCr2O4 catalyst [35], it is obvious that the barriers of Mn and V co-doping and Mn and Ti co-doping catalysts to the NH3 dehydrogenation reaction are significantly reduced. The barriers for the first dehydrogenation reaction of NH3 on the Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts were reduced from 1.01 eV to 0.91 and 0.97 eV, respectively. The potential barriers were reduced from 2.39 eV to 2.28 and 2.17 eV, respectively, and the barriers of the final dehydrogenation reaction were reduced from 1.76 eV to 0.87 and 0.95 eV, respectively. In other words, the two types of co-doping are indeed conducive to NH3 dehydrogenation to generate more NH2 intermediate products, which is conducive to subsequent reactions. 3.2.2 NH3-SCR reaction As previous reported [35], we know that after NH3 dissociates from a hydrogen atom on the surface of the catalyst to form NH2, NO molecules will approach NH2, and then directly combine with N atoms to form an intermediate NH2NO. However, NH2NO is unstable and easily decomposes, eventually generating H2O and N2. The decomposition process of NH2NO generated on Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4, Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst is shown in Fig. 7 . First, one H atom of NH2NO will be attracted by the lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface to form OH, and NH2NO will remove one H to form NHNO. Then, on the NHNO fragment the chemical bond between N and O is broken, and the last H ion is separated from the remaining NHN and is attracted by O atoms to form OH. After removing the H ion, only N2 molecules remain at the Mn site. Finally, OH can react with H on the surface to form the final product H2O. The decomposition of NH2NO eventually generates N2 and H2O, completing the main process of the SCR reaction. Compared with the previous work that only doped Mn, the co-doping of Mn and V or Mn and Ti can significantly promote the decomposition of NH2NO. The barriers for the first decomposition of NH2NO decreased from 0.59 to 0.37 and 0.42 eV and for subsequent NHNO decomposition decreased from 0.44 to 0.33 and 0.38 eV. Finally, the barriers generated by H2O decreased from 0.39 to 0.28 and 0.32 eV. Obviously, during the entire reaction process, the energy barrier is reduced and the reaction heat is increased, which is beneficial to the progress of the reaction. And the co-doping of Mn and V has a more obvious promoting effect than Mn and Ti, because V has relatively stronger oxidizing properties. 3.3 The SCR NOx removal reaction process on aerobic conditions 3.3.1 The decomposition of O2 During the adsorption-conversion process of the reactants, O2 can greatly promote the adsorption of NO. First, the presence of O2 will greatly increase the amount of nitrate produced on the catalyst surface, such as NO2, bidentate coordination nitrate and monodentate coordination nitrate. Secondly, oxygen is adsorbed on the catalyst surface and dissociated into two active oxygen anions, and then the active oxygen ions can promote the dehydrogenation process of NH3 molecules. When O2 is present, it will be adsorbed on the catalyst surface. The two O atoms are, respectively, connected with Mn ions, V or Ti ions on the catalyst surface, and a large number of electrons (-0.64 e and -0.59 e, respectively), will be transferred from the catalyst surface to O2 molecules. The adsorption energies of O2 molecules on Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 (100) are -3.71 eV and -3.44 eV, respectively, which means that with the adsorption of O2, the released lots of energy. Subsequently, the oxygen molecules dissociate into two reactive oxygen atoms on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 8 , the activation energies of the oxygen dissociation process on the Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts are 0.57 eV and 0.59 eV, respectively, and the reaction heats are -0.42 eV and -0.38 eV. It is worth noting that the large amount of energy released by the oxygen adsorption process is sufficient to compensate for the energy barrier of the dissociation process. 3.3.2 The dehydrogenation of adsorbed NH3 under the effect of adsorbed O anion When the oxygen molecule dissociates into two reactive oxygen anions, NH3 adsorbed on the catalyst surface will react with O ions. Fig. 9 shows the energy distributions and corresponding optimized structures of the reactions over the Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts. The reactive oxygen anion attracts the adjacent H atom in NH3 molecule to form OH, and NH3 becomes NH2 fragment, the activation energy barrier and reaction heat of this process on Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst are 0.66 eV and 0.54 eV, respectively. The activation energy barrier and reaction heat of this process over the Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst are 0.67 eV and 0.57 eV, respectively. Compared with the 1.01 eV barrier of NH3 direct dehydrogenation, NH3 adsorbed on the surface tends to react with active O in the presence of O2, because active O has more coordination numbers to bind more H atoms. After NH2 is generated, it can react with NO to form NH2NO, and then decompose. This is the same as the reaction process under anaerobic conditions shown in Figs. 6 and 7. We know that NH3 dehydrogenation plays an important role in SCR process. Therefore, the presence of oxygen greatly promotes the SCR process. 3.3.3 The formation of NO2 under the action of active O ions When there is active oxygen on the surface, NO will combine with it to generate NO2, and the reaction equation is α-NO+α-O→α-NO2. NO2 is the reactant of "fast SCR" reaction, therefore, exploring the formation of NO2 can be used to evaluate the catalytic activity of Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts. The energy distribution formed by NO2 and the corresponding optimized structure are shown in Fig. 10 . It can be seen that the O atom combined with V on the Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst and the N atom of NO adsorbed on the Mn site tend to attract and combine with each other to form a -NO2- structure. The activation energy barrier and reaction of the reaction heat is 0.13 eV and -0.55 eV, respectively, the O atom bound to Ti on the Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst and the N atom of NO adsorbed on the Mn site tend to attract and combine with each other to form a -NO2- structure. The reaction activation energy barrier and reaction heat are 0.14 eV and -0.51 eV, respectively. We can find that in both co-doped catalysts, the activation energy barrier for NO formation is very low and the reactions are both exothermic, indicating that the adsorbed NO molecules are prone to trap the active O ions and oxidize them to NO. After NO2 is generated, it will combine with the lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface to generate NO3-, and then easily combine with adsorbed or free NH3 to generate NH4NO3. However, NH4NO3 is not stable enough and can be reduced to NH4NO2 by NO, and then decomposed into N2 and H2O by heating. The reaction steps are as follows: NH4NO3 + NO ↔ NH4NO2 + NO2 NH4NO2 → N2 + 2H2O 3.4 Study on the sulfur resistance and water resistance of the catalyst In the actual reaction, there are some gases, such as H2O, SO2, etc., which may cause toxic effects on the SCR reaction. Therefore, in addition to the catalyst activity, the anti-toxicity of the catalyst is also an important research content. 3.4.1 Study on the water resistance of the catalyst H2O molecules usually compete with NH3 and NOx species for adsorption and occupy active sites, which will adversely affect the SCR process. Therefore, the structure of H2O molecules adsorbed on the Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4, Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts is shown in Fig. 11 . The adsorption energies of H2O on the Co, Cr, Mn and V sites of Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 are -1.31, -1.09, -1.26 and -0.91 eV, respectively. The adsorption energies of H2O on the Co, Cr, Mn and V sites of Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 are -0.65, -0.92, -0.61 and -0.87 eV, respectively. It is obvious that the adsorption of H2O on the two co-doped catalysts is much weaker than that of NH3 adsorbed on them, especially on the co-doped Mn and Ti catalysts. This means that H2O will hardly have an adverse effect on NH3 adsorption, and the two co-doped catalysts have good water resistance. 3.4.2 Study on the anti-sulfur performance of the catalyst SO2 is widely present in flue gas and can cause catalyst sulfur poisoning. The toxic effect of SO2 on the catalyst is due to the sulfation of the catalyst surface under the action of SO2. On the one hand, SO2 reacts with NH3 on the catalyst surface to form (NH4)2SO4 or NH4HSO4. These ammonium sulfate salts will cover the surface of the catalyst, blocking the pores of the catalyst, affecting the adsorption and diffusion of the reaction gas, and then reducing its activity. We have calculated the adsorption of SO2 on the three catalysts Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4, Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4, respectively, and the corresponding optimized configurations are shown in Fig. 12 . The adsorption energy of SO2 on the CoCr2O4 catalyst doped with only Mn is relatively strong, even the adsorption energies of SO2 on the Mn and Co sites are greater than the adsorption energy of NH3, which will cause competitive adsorption, thereby inhibiting the adsorption of NH3 by the catalyst and activation. On the Mn, V co-doped and Mn, Ti co-doped CoCr2O4 catalyst, the adsorption energies of SO2 at several active sites are lower than the adsorption energies of NH3, especially above the Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst, the adsorption of SO2 is significantly inhibited, which will not compete with the adsorption of NH3. NH3 can be adsorbed and activated on the active sites on the catalyst surface, and subsequent catalytic reactions will occur. Therefore, the co-doping of Mn and Ti on the surface of the CoCr2O4 catalyst can effectively improve the sulfur resistance of the catalyst. SO2 in the flue gas is easily oxidized by O2 to form SO3, which may react with H2O and NH3: SO3+NH3+H2O→NH4HSO4, thereby forming NH4HSO4. The deposition of ammonium bisulfate on the catalyst surface will cause the pores of the catalyst to be blocked and the active sites on the surface to be covered, thereby inhibiting the performance of the catalyst. Therefore, we calculated the adsorption behavior of NH4HSO4 on three catalysts, Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4, Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4, and the corresponding adsorption structures are shown in Fig. 13 . It can be clearly seen that NH4HSO4 is strongly adsorbed on the Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4 catalyst, and its adsorption energy is -2.51 eV. On the co-doped catalyst, the adsorption energy of NH4HSO4 is significantly reduced, especially in the Mn and Ti co-doped catalyst, the adsorption energy of NH4HSO4 is only -0.94 eV. This also means that the co-doping of Mn and Ti on the surface of the CoCr2O4 catalyst can effectively improve the anti-poisoning performance of the catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this paper, DFT calculations are used to simulate the selective catalytic reduction mechanism of NH3 on Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4, Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts. On the catalysts co-doped with Mn and V and Mn and Ti, the adsorption of NH3, NO, NO2 on the catalyst is enhanced, and the amount of Mulliken charge transfer increases, indicating that Mn, V co-doping and Mn, Ti co-doping can cause Electron migration on the surface of the catalyst and dislocations in the surface lattice as well as increasing the activity of the acidic sites on the surface, which dramatically improves the adsorption performance of the catalyst. NH3 is adsorbed on the catalyst, and then dehydrogenation reaction occurs, which is decomposed into NH2, NH and N fragments. Among them, the NH2 produced by the first dehydrogenation of NH3 is the focus of research. Our calculation results show that the first step of NH3 dehydrogenation barrier on the catalyst is reduced from 1.01 to 0.91 and 0.97 eV after Mn and V co-doping with Mn and Ti co-doping compared with only doping Mn. The NH2 generated on the surface of the catalyst will further react with gaseous NO molecules to generate NH2NO intermediate products. After that, NH2NO will decompose into N2 and H2O on the catalyst surface. We compared the decomposition process of NH2NO formed on the surface of Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4, Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4. The calculation results found that the co-doping of Mn and V and the co-doping of Mn and Ti reduced the maximum barriers for the decomposition of NH2NO from 0.59 eV to 0.37 and 0.42 eV, respectively. When oxygen is present in the reaction atmosphere, it adsorbs on the catalyst surface and then dissociates to form two reactive oxygen ions. Active oxygen can promote the dehydrogenation process of NH3, thereby greatly improving the removal efficiency of NOx. NO also reacts with the active O on the surface to form NO2, and then a "fast SCR" reaction occurs on the catalyst surface. In addition, studies on the water resistance and sulfur resistance of the catalyst showed that the adsorption of H2O, SO2 and NH4HSO4 on the Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalyst was significantly lower than that on the Mn0.1Co0.9Cr2O4 catalyst, that is to say, the co-doping of Mn and Ti can effectively improve the water resistance and sulfur resistance of the catalyst. In summary, the co-doping of Mn and V and the co-doping of Mn and Ti on the surface of the CoCr2O4 catalyst can improve the performance of NH3 in the selective catalytic reduction of NOx, and the co-doping effect of Mn-V is more obvious. The co-doping of Mn and Ti can significantly improve the water resistance and sulfur resistance of the catalyst. Our research can provide theoretical guidance for the study of transition metal doped cobalt-chromium spinel catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Being based on the first-principles calculation method of density functional theory, our work calculated the optimized configuration of CoCr2O4(100) before and after co-doping of Mn and V(Ti). The adsorption behaviors of NH3, NO, NO2 and other gas molecules on the catalyst before and after doping were simulated. The optimized structures and related energy distribution of NH3 dehydrogenation reaction and SCR reaction on Mn0.1Co0.9V0.1Cr1.9O4 and Mn0.1Co0.9Ti0.1Cr1.9O4 catalysts were also fully studied. Our results reveal that the co-doping of heteroatom towards CoCr2O4(100) may result in electron migration and lattice dislocations as well as improving the surface acid activity. Therefore, the co-doping of Mn and V or Mn and Ti are believed to improve the adsorption of NH3, NO, NO2 and other gas molecules on the CoCr2O4 catalyst and significantly reduce the activation energy barrier of the NH3 dehydrogenation reaction and the SCR reaction. Furthermore, we studied the adsorption of SO2 and H2O on the co-doped catalyst, which exhibited that the co-doping of Mn and Ti may effectively improve the water and sulfur resistance of the catalyst. Our research are expected to be full of important theoretical guiding significance for the development, preparation and modification of cobalt-chromium spinel catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Study on the mechanism of NOx reduction by NH3-SCR over Mn and M(M=V,Ti) co-doped CoCr2O4 catalyst
